courses.title: The Design of Everyday Things
courses.author: Donald A. Norman
courses.description: Extraordinary design is not done by geniuses.
relevant-for: Anyone - who wants to understand why everyday objects work (or don't work)
Entrepreneurs - building products that users intuitively understand
UX Designers - creating interfaces that guide user behavior
Product Managers - making design decisions based on user psychology

content.title: Doors, Handles, and Hidden Messages
text-segments: Every day, objects silently communicate what they want you to do with them.
A door handle says 'pull me', a flat metal plate whispers 'push here'.
In this course, we'll explore the fundamental principle of design: affordances.

content.title: The Hook
text-segments: Look at this kettle.
image-link[no-blur]:assets/kettle.png
What's wrong with this design?
The handle is on <c:r>the same side</c:r> as the spout.
When you try to pour hot water, your hand is directly over the escaping steam.
This is a classic example Don Norman uses to show <c:r>bad design</c:r> - it looks elegant, but it's dangerous to use.
Good design isn't just about aesthetics; it must prioritize <c:g>usability</c:g> and <c:g>safety</c:g> above all.
In the following slides, we'll read stories that show how these principles work in real design challenges.

content.title: Story 1
text-segments: Sarah approaches the hotel door.
Glass panel with a vertical metal plate.
The plate looks like a handle.
Her brain screams "pull this!"
What choice did evolution give her?
She grabs and pulls. Nothing.
Confused, she pushes. The door opens.
This is a Norman door.
It gives the wrong signal.

content.title: Story 2
text-segments: Emma approaches the conference room door.
It's entirely made of glass.
No visible handle, no obvious push point.
The surface is completely smooth.
She pushes where others have pushed.
Smudges on the glass are her only clue.
The door swings open.
Poor affordances left her guessing.
Good design would show her the way.

content.title: Story 3
text-segments: Alex finds a sleek modern water bottle.
The cap looks like it should twist off.
He turns it counterclockwise. Nothing.
He tries clockwise. Still stuck.
Finally, he notices it's a flip-top.
The cap hinges upward, not twist.
The bottle's design suggested the wrong action.
This is what designers call false affordances.
Objects that lie about their function.

content.title: Door Design
content.question: Quick question: When you see a door with a handle, what does your brain assume?
content.explanation: Handles suggest pulling. This is called an "affordance" - what the design tells you to do.
content.hint: Think about what action a handle naturally suggests when you grab it.

options.consequence-message: This is a correct thought - that would be the right action to take.
You'd struggle and feel confused - the handle design strongly suggests pulling, not pushing.
While polite, this is not the action suggested by the handle's design.

content.title: Glass Door Mystery
content.question: Why was Emma confused by the glass door?

options.text: It provided no visual clues about how to open it
options.consequence-message: Correct understanding - poor affordances leave users guessing.
Transparency isn't the issue - even opaque doors need clear interaction cues.
Time pressure doesn't excuse poor design - good affordances work under any circumstances.

content.explanation: The door lacked affordances - visual or physical cues that indicate how it should be used.
content.hint: Consider what visual information the door provided about its operation.

content.title: Water Bottle Confusion
content.question: Why did Alex struggle with the water bottle cap?

options.text: The design suggested twisting when it actually flipped
options.consequence-message: Exactly! False affordances mislead users into wrong actions.
Good design shouldn't require instructions - the object should be self-explanatory.
This would be a mechanical issue, not a design problem - the visual cues were misleading.

content.explanation: This is a false affordance - the design suggests one action while requiring another.
content.hint: Think about what action the cap's appearance suggested versus what was actually needed.

content.title: What Are Affordances?
text-segments: Those three scenarios reveal something profound about how objects communicate.
Each confusion wasn't random - it reveals how <c:g>design shapes our expectations and actions</c:g>.
Don Norman studied these patterns and identified <c:g>affordances</c:g> as a fundamental principle of intuitive design.
Understanding affordances transforms how you see every interface, from door handles to smartphone apps.

content.title: Affordances
text-segments: The first principle is <c:g>affordances</c:g> - the relationship between an object's properties and what actions they suggest to users.
<c:g>A door handle</c:g> naturally affords grasping and pulling, while <c:g>a flat metal plate</c:g> clearly affords pushing.
<c:g>Good affordances</c:g> are immediately obvious - you know what to do without thinking or reading instructions.
<c:r>Poor affordances</c:r> mislead users into taking wrong actions, creating the illusion of user error when it's actually design failure.

content.title: Types of Affordances
text-segments: Objects can provide different types of affordances to guide user behavior.
<c:g>Visual affordances</c:g> use appearance - a raised button looks pressable, a handle looks graspable.
<c:g>Physical affordances</c:g> use shape and texture - a groove suggests sliding, ridges suggest gripping.
<c:g>Cultural affordances</c:g> rely on learned conventions - red means stop, green means go.

content.title: The USB Mystery
content.question: Why does a USB cable never fit on the first try?

options.text: The USB exists in quantum superposition
options.consequence-message: Funny theory, but the real issue is design - USBs should have clear visual indicators for correct orientation.

options.text: Poor visual design makes orientation unclear
options.consequence-message: Exactly! Good design would make the correct orientation immediately obvious.

content.explanation: USB connectors look identical from both sides. Good design makes orientation obvious.
content.hint: Consider what visual information the USB connector provides to help users orient it correctly.

content.title: Affordances in Practice
text-segments: <c:g>Great designers</c:g> use affordances to guide behavior without instruction.
<c:g>A well-designed slider</c:g> has a groove that suggests the direction of movement.
<c:g>Raised buttons</c:g> suggest pressing, while <c:r>flat areas that look clickable but aren't</c:r> confuse users.
The <c:g>best affordances</c:g> feel so natural that you don't even notice them working.

content.title: Affordance Check
content.question: True or false: A good affordance requires written instructions to understand.

options.consequence-message: You'd be designing objects that confuse users and require constant explanation - the opposite of intuitive design.
Exactly! You understand that great design speaks for itself without needing instruction manuals.

content.explanation: False! Good affordances are immediately obvious and require no explanation. If you need instructions, the affordance has failed.
content.hint: Think about the best-designed objects you use - do they need labels?

content.title: Complete the Principle
content.question: Fill in the blanks: Affordances are the _____ between object properties and the _____ they suggest.
content.explanation: Affordances are the relationship between object properties and the actions they suggest. This fundamental definition shows how design communicates function.
content.hint: Think back to Norman's original definition of affordances.

content.title: Design Principle Check
content.question: Good design should require extensive user manuals to understand.

options.consequence-message: You'd create products that frustrate users and generate countless support tickets - design should be self-explanatory.
Perfect! You recognize that intuitive design eliminates the need for extensive documentation.

content.explanation: Good design should be intuitive and self-explanatory. If it needs a manual, the design has failed to communicate its function clearly.

content.title: Door Study Results
content.question: In Norman's study of door-related accidents, what percentage of people pulled a push door on their first attempt?
content.explanation: Norman found that 73% of people initially pulled doors that were meant to be pushed when the door had a vertical handle. This demonstrates how powerful affordances are - handles strongly suggest pulling, regardless of signage.

content.title: Affordance Examples
text-segments: <c:g>Great affordances</c:g> work invisibly - you use them without thinking.
<c:g>Scissors</c:g> have finger holes that show exactly where to place your fingers.
<c:g>A zipper tab</c:g> moves up and down along an obvious track.
Good affordances make the correct action feel <c:g>inevitable and natural</c:g>.

content.title: Affordances in Your Life
content.prompt: Think about an object you use daily that has excellent affordances. What makes it so intuitive?
thinking-points: What visual or physical cues guide your behavior?
How does the design suggest the correct action?
Would this object work for someone who's never seen it before?
What would happen if the affordances were removed?

content.title: Skill Check 1
content.question: A door has a horizontal bar across it. According to the principle of affordances, what should you do?

options.consequence-message: You'd struggle unnecessarily - horizontal bars are designed for pushing, not pulling.

options.text: Push the door away from you
options.consequence-message: Perfect! Horizontal bars (crash bars) are specifically designed to afford pushing.

content.explanation: A horizontal bar (also called a crash bar or panic bar) affords pushing. This is a clear affordance that indicates the door should be pushed to open.
content.hint: Think about what action a horizontal bar naturally suggests.

content.title: Skill Check 2
content.question: You see a button that looks flat against the surface. What does this affordance suggest?

options.consequence-message: Flat surfaces typically suggest non-interactive areas - raised or recessed buttons afford pressing.
Correct! Flat surfaces afford no interaction - they don't invite pressing or manipulation.
Sliding is afforded by grooves or tracks, not flat surfaces.

content.explanation: Flat surfaces that blend with their surroundings don't afford pressing. Good button design uses shadows, borders, or depth to clearly afford interaction.
content.hint: Think about what visual properties make something look pressable.

content.title: Skill Check 3
content.question: Which design better affords opening: a drawer with a visible handle or one with a smooth, handleless front?

options.text: The drawer with a visible handle
options.consequence-message: Exactly! A handle clearly affords pulling - its shape and position make the action obvious.
Without a handle, users must guess where and how to open it - poor affordance leads to confusion.

content.explanation: Handles are one of the clearest affordances - they show exactly where to grasp and suggest the pulling action. Handleless designs sacrifice clarity for aesthetics.
content.hint: Consider which design immediately communicates how to interact with it.

content.title: The Conversation Continues
text-segments: So what do you do when a door confuses you at the entrance? When buttons give no response?
Next time you encounter a Norman door, you'll recognize the design flaw, not user error.
When you design something – a presentation, an app, even an email – ask yourself: <c:g>Is my intent obvious?</c:g>
Remember: <c:g>good affordances</c:g> reveal purpose, while <c:r>poor affordances</c:r> hide it.
The principle of affordances applies everywhere – from <c:r>confusing coffee machines</c:r> to <c:g>intuitive smartphone interfaces</c:g>.
Good design isn't about being clever. It's about being <c:g>clear</c:g>.
